content: The federal K-12 education legislation, starting from the Improving America's Schools Act in 1994 to the No Child Left Behind Act in 2001, has focused on granting flexibility to grantees. This flexibility allows for waivers of federal program requirements for state and local aid recipients who meet certain criteria. The report provides an overview of these authorizations and will be updated as needed to reflect new developments. The federal K-12 education legislation grants flexibility to state and local aid recipients by waiving federal program requirements for those meeting eligibility criteria. This flexibility includes provisions for consolidating programs, transferring funds, and waiving specific requirements under the Elementary and Secondary Education Act (ESEA). However, the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) is not included in these flexibility authorities. The report discusses federal involvement in K-12 education through the ESEA, excluding the IDEA. It reviews program requirements, special flexibility authorities, and cross-cutting issues.
